Reviews.Content: From the POV of a well-travelled adult couple looking for a first class resort experience: We weren't quite as happy with this resort as others seem to be. The room (15th floor Deluxe Ocean View) was smaller than expected and included a view that was part ocean, part industrial. The neighbouring room's balcony had a clear view of our bed and dressing areas, which required careful attention to the arrangement of the plantation style shutters to allow light and air while blocking unwanted attention. The staff could not move us to the other side and we were stuck with the refinery, the lack of privacy, and with pool noise. The noise wasn't terrible on our high floor, but any lower and it would have been unacceptable. Ask for the "sunset view" if you're booking an ocean view before you arrive and ask about the arrangement of the neighbouring balconies. The concierge, front desk and valet parking staff were competent and helpful. The housekeeping staff was inconsistent and we had to remind them several times to refresh items. The hotel restaurants are disappointing. If you have foodie pretensions (we do) you won't be satisfied. They charge first class prices and provide food and service that is of chain restaurant quality. The wine list at Azul is spectacular, but completely out of proportion to the quality of the food and service. Usho Tei has weird overhead flourescent lighting more suitable to a fast food joint. Their sushi was OK, but the selection was limited to the basics. Naupaka Terrace drove us to drive into Honolulu to eat breakfast at Longhi's in the Ala Moana Center when we were looking for more than coffee and bagels. Roy's at the golf club has a decent reputation, but based on our one visit, it's as noisy as a cafeteria and the service is more like a rugby scrum than fine dining. I'm afraid you'll have to travel a fair distance into Honolulu to find truly excellent dining. (Chef Mavro and Alan Wong's are worth the price and the travel.) The bar was better than the restaurants, with good pupus and well made drinks. The entertainment at the bar (Thu, Fri and Sat only) was by a very laid back acoustic guitar player/singer. Sitting at the large open windows, looking out at the darkening ocean over the palm tops with a terrific drink and some soft music made up for a lot of other things. The nearby Paradise Cove luau show was fun, but have something to eat before you go and take a pass on the food. It won't save you money, but your tastebuds will thank you. Whether you're up for the hokey games and ceremonies before the show is your call. The lagoon beaches are OK, but the selection of activities is limited and of course there is no beach service (illegal in HI). A little boring for adults after a couple of days. The golf course was interesting and challenging and pretty much as advertised. My wife enjoyed her half day at the spa, and rated it good, but not extraordinary. All in all, it doesn't quite squeak into our definition of a five star resort. We spent far too much time on the H1 and in Honolulu traffic, driving elsewhere to find some fun, and the hotel management needs to pull up their food and room standards. Perhaps when the higher end time share buildings are up, and the rumoured Ritz-Carlton is built, they will reach a critical mass in Ko Olina that will support better restaurants and entertainment, but for now it's not a good value and a tad boring.

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel!”
Reviews.Author: Mtgs_My-Life
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the hotel for an extended weekend celebrating our 20th wedding anniversary. The hotel upgraded us to a wonderful overview room (Marriott Platinum member) and a bottle of wine upon arrival. The free coffee in the morning in the lobby was a great way to start the day. We read January 1's "True Tips about Ko Olina" and other reviews before arriving. As far as the concierge, I believe they are sub-contracted, and usually not that helpful unless you want to book and tour and they can make some money. The best source of information is their great staff. We have a great talk with the pool attendant that gave us advice for seeing surfing on the north shore. We lucked out and saw the Monster Energey Drink Pipeline competition, and thanks to his advice got their early for a parking spot. We were there just before the Pro Bowl, so the football goalposts were up already. We had our anniversary dinner at Roy's restaurant, nearby and it was fantastic! They made a wonderful special dessert for us!

Reviews.Title: “Great hotel”
Reviews.Author: fischman44
Reviews.Content: I'm not a fan of Oahu overall as I think it's too crowded and not a reflection of the "real" Hawaii. Having said that, my wife and I really enjoyed this property and highly recommend it. Rooms were nice, great service and you are away from the hustle and bustle of the city.

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous resort and surprisingly child friendly.”
Reviews.Author: Kiwidoc
Reviews.Content: I can't say enough about this beautiful resort. We stayed there for 5 nights in April 2005 with our then 20 month old son and were treated like royalty the entire time. The room we had was elegant and spacious with a large balcony overlooking the ocean and a huge luxurious marble bathroom. We brought our own portable crib with us and found there was more than enough room to accomodate it without crowding the space. As hotels of this caliber are sometimes not especially "child friendly" were delighted to find out how welcoming everyone was towards a small child. There was so much for him to do every day from the daily fish feeding at the lagoon to the stingray pond in the entrance (which was a major hit) and the sheltered lagoons which were rarely crowded are ideal for a toddler to swim in. We were also offered a complimentary luau and show at the nearby time-share resort which we all enjoyed immensly. (Apparently my husband is now a Samoan chief!) The resort is off the beaten track so you do really need a car unless you plan to stay there the whole time and as expected, the restaurants at the hotel are not inexpensive but we found the food was fabulous. The hotel and the grounds were beautifully landscaped as you would expect of a hotel in this class but the best thing about this resort is the staff. No snooty " 5 star" attitude here, everyone we encountered was helpful and friendly. Staff made a point of welcoming us back with a smile whenever we entered the property and went out of their way to make us feel like valued guests. Our son stumbled and fell once when he exited the elevator (his fault) but no sooner did a front desk agent see he was crying, than she came over to give him a stuffed toy and some candy. We have been fortunate to have stayed at many other 5 star resorts but this is by far the best experience we have had when traveling with a small child. Many thanks to everyone for a wonderful stay. We hope to be back again.

Reviews.Title: “The JW left me wanting moore!!!”
Reviews.Author: Boorzhwah
Reviews.Content: I am a diligent reader of hotel reviews whenever I plan trips for my wife and I, so I have decided to start writing them myself. As a side note I must say that a great majority of our trip was a blur because we found out that my wife was pregnant with our first child my son Blake who is due May 21st. So to the nitty gritty. We stayed at the JW Ihilani for 10 days in September to celebrate our 1 year anniversary. After planning for about 9 months to make this a great vacation I was pleased to read a majority of the reviews. I will now attempt to give you a brief but thorough review my way. I. The Transportation. You can not survive here without a car. We rented a convertible which was an added plus. If you are cold natured I do not suggest ridding around at night with the top down, the cool air there will sneak up on you! The ride into Waikiki is not bad at all, about 20 minutes, and the little city next to the resort is great. II. The Food. Food seems to be a major issue for everyone from the reviews that I have read. Yes the resort is pricey, but if you are relaxing and just don't feel like having valet bring your car up then you are trapped. The breakfast buffet is ok and room temp. The omelet station is acceptable and yes be prepared to pay about 40 to 50 dollars. Due to my wife’s morning sickness we ate room service quite frequently and it was quite good. Zippy's in town is an option for those wanting to save a dime but you will get tired of it quickly, they offer the usual breakfast suspects and of course they have the infamous SPAM. PLEASE budget for your food as it is all flown in and when you see an appetizer at Chili's for 14.00 don't pass out. There are great meals everywhere, be adventurous and try new places. Roy's was one of my favorites and it is a stones throw from the resort, great sushi, and steak!!! III. The Hotel. We are Marriott rewards members so I don't know if we received good service because of that but we certainly enjoyed the front desk staff. We were upgraded to a junior suite which provided the two of us with more than enough space, there were days in which we didn't even go into our adjoining room. The staff was courteous and the turndown service was a definite plus. The grounds were beautiful and well cared for. The stingray and shark pools were great as well. The concierge staff was ok but I do suggest that you do your research first and then just have them make the reservations for you. The rooms where well appointed and the smart phones were great. IV. The Island. I will keep this one short. We will be back time and time again and I live on the east coast. We did a great amount of damage with our shopping and enjoyed every minute. There is just this vibe there that calms your nerves and soothes the soul, must be the sun. In Closing. We are a travel happy couple, we try to travel every quarter for rest and relaxation so I m a little picky when it comes to my accommodations and this experience ranks right up there as one of the best. We had just visited Cancun in June and stayed at the Ritz Carlton and this experience was easily twice as nice. I highly recommend the JW Ihilani. The lagoons can't be beat for convenience. We travel with our own snorkeling gear and I was able to see a great variety of tropical fish and coral within feet of the resort. Overall I can't wait to go back, we are headed to the Bahamas next week for our babymoon but my heart is in Hawaii!!!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel on the peaceful side of Oahu”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This is a beautiful resort on the peaceful side of Oahu. The rooms are spacious and beautifully decorated. The area is really quiet. There is only one other hotel: The Marriott Vacation Club at Ko'Olina. Our room had an enormous door out to the deck with screen doors and sliding shutters allowing us to fall asleep listening the ocean...and the ocean breeze was fantastic. We didn't use the AC once! The balcony had a nice setup with a table, two chairs and a lounge chair. The bathroom was large with a two sinks, a separate soaking tub, a stand-up shower and a closed off toilet area. The beds are very comfortable For recreation, the hotel has a pool, a Jacuzzi and a lagoon directly in front of it that is perfect for snorkeling. (Bring your own-expensive to rent). There are actually several lagoons in Ko'Olina along the walking path leading to the Marriott Ko'Olina Vacation Club. All are available for snorkeling. (Don’t forget a to get a towel at the hotel before you visit the other lagoons) There are also Kayaks and water bikes for rent in front of both resorts. The only real drawback was the lack of restaurant choices. There are two restaurants and a pool side bar and grill. The food is really expensive in the restaurants and the bar & grill doesn’t have a lot of variety. I would suggest renting a car because most of the restaurants and all of the tourist locations in Oahu are about thirty minutes to an hour away.

Reviews.Title: “Great place for a relaxing vacation”
Reviews.Author: NanCa
Reviews.Content: A family group and I got back a week ago from a week-long vacation at this JW Marriott and we loved it. It is isolated from Honolulu, which we all thought was a good thing. We did go downtown one day and had lunch at the Royal Hawaiian Hotel (one of the grand old hotels right on the beach) and enjoyed that a lot, but we were very glad we weren't staying down there. Before going to the Royal Hawaiian for lunch, we toured Pearl Harbor. We arrived at the visitor center by 7:30 and were in the 5th group. But there is plenty to see while you're waiting for the boat to take you out to the Arizona. Compared to the downtown beaches, the Marriott beach was empty with comfortable chairs for your use. There are only a few umbrellas so we did get down early to reserve on those days we knew we'd be hanging out on the beach. We only swam and snorkeled in Lagoon 1. The water was warm (probably 78 degrees or so) and we saw great fish and even a couple of turtles while we were snorkeling. We did the timeshare presentation for 90 minutes one afternoon and were able to get $100 passes for the dolphin watch/snorkeling boat that goes out of the marina at Lagoon 4. We also did the Fia Fia luau which was eh. I'm glad I did it and the food was good, but it went on too long with too much audience participation (probably to give the dancers some downtime). But you do need to stay to the end of the show - their finale was the best part. The one downside of the Marriott area is the lack of restaurants nearby. We went to the nearby Roys twice (which was fantastic) and drove to an Italian restaurant about a half-hour away one night, ate at the hotel one night (pricey but very good), and called out for pizza one night. For breakfast they do sell pastries in the lobby in the morning where they also have the free (and delicious) coffee available. Great resort, everyone very friendly and helpful. If Hawaii wasn't so far away, I'd go back again.

Reviews.Title: “TimeShare place, not a full service hotel”
Reviews.Author: raprice
Reviews.Content: Loved the lagoons and pools, great beach areas. All else about the beach resort was less than expected quality. Rooms small, not sound insulated and NOT very private so it was not worth the full service hotel price we paid. I did accept a handicapped accessible room so that may have made the room less satisfactory.

Reviews.Title: “Fab-u-lous”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We thoroughly enjoyed are stay at the JW Marriott in Ko Olina. All of the staff was extremely pleasant and made us feel right at home. Although Ko Olina is 30 minutes outside of Honolulu it is well worth the drive. After visiting the congested Waikiki area we were pleased that we had chosen to stay in Ko Olina. The property has four beautiful, picture perfect, lagoons and a wonderful spa. The food was good. I really enjoyed the Margarita omelet from room service and the bar above the pool had wonderful martinis for $4.00 (after 9 pm) with a cigar bar feel. The only complaint I have is the service at the Japanese restaurant was awful. We received are drinks 45 minutes after ordering. If we ever go back to Oahu we will definitely stay at the JW Marriott.

Reviews.Title: “True Tips about Ko Olina”
Reviews.Author: cooldoctor1
Reviews.Content: Print this out for your trip. Stayed at Ko Olina from Dec 24 - Jan 1, 2006. Loved it, and the photos give you some idea. The other reviews say much, but here are the tips. Tip: you must have a car if you stay here; although your entire trip on Waikiki Beach could be car-less, using the bus and tours, here you are about 28 miles away from Waikiki Beach (a good thing). You can use the valet (they drive like maniacs) or park your own car each trip out in the four story garage--always spaces. Either way, your bill will have a $13/day parking charge. We prefer to go in and out when we choose. Tip: free hot cofee in lobby each AM, and great place to have quiet time at 0300 (which is 0700 central time). Tip: the restaurants are pricey (Xmas buffett that was slightly better than Hometown Buffett chain was $50 per person w/out tax or tip or any mixed drinks!) and thus you must drive for good eats on H1, but very easy as few cars out on this part of island. 8 miles away is Barber Park exit (staff has directions if you inquire) with Kmart, Outback Steakhouse, Home Depot and movie theaters. 14 miles inbound on H1 is Kunia Road, with Wal-Mart, many small oriental food restaurants, and a fabulous pasta house called Auntie Pesto's; crowded at night, but great lunches! Also use Kunia Road to travel to the North Shore, Haleiwea and Banzaii Pipeline; a nice route over the mountain by the DelMonte plantations, Ko Olina is a fast 30 mile ride to the north shore via Kunia Rd (less congested than H1 to H2). See my pic of Waimea Bach Park, with few parking thus get there early (like 0800) for a free spot. Also, know that you can take the stunning H1 to H3 across the island to Kunia Bach Park on the east side and have lunch outdoors at Kuleawa Market. Bottom line, you can get anywhere on the island (Dole Plantation tour, Poly Cult Ctr, etc) more easily from Ko Olina than you can from Waikiki Beach, period. Once at Ko Olina is is all Ko Olina, beach homes, townhomes, golf ($170/round!) all owned by Marriott once you get past the gatehouse. Tip: the best rooms are over the pool (despite prior reviewers) if you want a direct ocean view and don't mind every day from 530pm to 8pm some live light rock music poolside). Higher floor better. The two side to the resort, also ocean views (this was my view) and rather than just open ocean, can actually see more trees and mountains. Caution: the lagoon side of hotel is better than the non-lagoon (which we had) as the Laua makes a big raquet of noise nightly until 10pm. Worst rooms are any that face the spa or carport entrance side. Best bet, ask for any room that does not face this and you are okay, and any rooms that face the lagoon or pool, esp high floor, is gorgeous. Tip: ask for breakfast buffett coupon, and they will work into rate; the buffett should you pay for it is $23 each! But they discount for you when you book, and it is a great way to start each day (basic buffett but still hearty, we ate there every day) before spending rest of day by pool or driving around island (and avoiding Waikiki Beach). Tip: each room has a fridge with expensive stuff, but you can move it out and put your own sodas in there (but cannot store a bunch of stuff); they give one ice bucket daily when they clean the rms unless you ask for more. Tip: you must get to the poolside on weekends and in crowds by no later than 0730 AM to get a chair. Everyone catches on and throws a towel and a book on a chair, even though some don;t arrive until 11Am to use the pool! It is a disgrace, we even spoke to the pool manager about it and they have no, and seem not to care to have a, policy about unoccupied chairs. Anyhow, then play their game. A great day at Ko Olina would be to awaken at 0300 (keeping on central mainland time), free coffee and newspapers in the lobby, throw a towel on the pool chairs by 0600 (ha ha, beat them at thier own game), enjoy the spacisou nand clean lobby near the shark tank and stingrays. Each breakfast at 0630 or so, when it opens (big weekend waits after 0800), when it is clean and the food fresh. Then either hit the pool or lagoons (ta DA, you have a chair), or drive up the North SHore (saw training for surf competition including Kelly Slater at Eukhai Beach--ask staff for directions) via Kunia, or easy H3 to Kaneohoe Bay and Kulia Lanaki for the day, or Dole (a ripoff) or Poly Cult Ctr; it's all there-- you will beat the rush for parking by being there around 0900. Enjoy the day, then eat at one of the exits I mentionj en route back to hotel around 3pm (again, beating dinner crowd and in Oahu most resturants serve lunch speciasl until 4pm), and get your suntan lotions, magazines, etc at the Kmart or Wal-mart, then back to Ko Olina by 5pm for the poolside music, then hit the sack at 7pm (11pm central time)... best of all worlds! I do not agree that staying on mainland time is a disadvantage, it actually works well to beat everyone to the punch. Ko Olina is, as everyone says, fabulous. Have a car, expect easy driving and parking, and enjoy.

Reviews.Title: “Nothing Special”
Reviews.Author: chenson
Reviews.Content: I arrived on 11/29/05 for 6 nights. The was my 2nd stop on a 14 day vacation to Hawaii. This was my "least favorite" hotel and island. The found the hotel moderate for a "supposedly lush location". We had a ocean front room, nicely decorated, a little hard to control the temprature, the bathroom was the nicest feature. The food was ""extremely"" repetative and really not that good. Matter fact we hard hard time getting a good meal at all in Oahu. The pool was extremely small and very cold. The lagoon was probaly the only really nice feature of the hotel along with the convenience to the highway. I'm a Marriott reward member and stay at Marriotts all the time, it was clean, but for a JW this was absolutely nothing special! If I had to rate it I wouldnt pay over $170/nt. Again, in Hawaii you need a car for everything. The traffic is horendous - its like a small city and if you want to see something rustic you need to drive 1 hr or more. Oh.. dont waste your time going to a hula show - its no different than on TV - the food is awful and you end up wasting $75/pp. I heard mixed reviews on the show, but if you in Hawaii you need to see the show right? Wrong save your night and do something else - maybe swin with the sharks (really neat).

Reviews.Title: “An Oasis on Oahu”
Reviews.Author: JasonLab
Reviews.Content: If you like quiet, classy, spotless, newer-style resorts with Vegas sized rooms and amenities, then try the JW. The virtually private sandy beach was beautiful and calm. The staff was fantastic and even the food at the pool was tasty (we didn't have a chance to eat at the other on-site restaurants). After staying in Maui and having a great experience there, I didn't think my vacation with my girlfriend could get any better. After all, Maui is typically considered the nicer and more romantic island. Well, Ko Olina could just be the resort to rival Kaanapali. All of the food, shopping, tourist activities and airport of Honolulu are just 25 minutes to the East, so there is no shortage of things to do. And I think that's what made this particular location so perfect. The city is close, while this resort feels so far away. Perfect for couples.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing experiance”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I traveled to the JW Marriott in Hawaii with my parents and friend for spring break last year, my freshman year in highschool, and it was amazing. The year before we stayed at the JW Marriott in Cancun, and just loved it. So, I was a little bit nervous going to a new place, but it was just amazing. We stayed in a upgraded room, very big, and very nice. The bay was amazing. You could rent canoes, snorkleing gear, and water bikes, for very reasonable costs. The staff was amazing, very attentave and kind. The food on the resort was very good, and the breakfast was expensive, but very delicious. This resort is very far from Waikiki beach, you have no one desturbing you, and it is completly tranquil. The is another Marriott just down the road that you can walk to, and they also have some nice ammenities you take part in as a JW guest. The resort is in a community with a golf course, and everyone is very friendly. One thing to watch out for: On the weekends this hotel get sinificantly busier due to locals that come for pool and ocean use, but everyone is still very friendly. The Spa area is very nice, and in a separate building from the hotel for extra peace and quiet. It is an amazing place to stay, and I highly recommend it!

Reviews.Title: “Traci from Ewa Beach is the best house keeper”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I bring my family to visit oahu twice a year and we love staying at the JW mariott Ihilani in Ko Olina but the first time we stayed there, the house keeper did a very lousy job on our suite. For the first couple days, its been hell. But one day, we walked into our suite and we thought we walked into a the wrong door. The house keeper did a fantastic job but she wasn't done yet and we did not want to startle her so my husband took my kids to the game room and I waited close by so that I could catch a glimps of her name. On her name tag, it said "Traci". I couldn't remember what was on there but I believe underneath her name it said Ewa Beach. I just wanted to let you know that she is doing a fantistic job and she deserve a really good raise or something good. My family and I are planning to come and visit again in March and we rather stay at your Ko Olina than anywhere else, just as long there is Traci Ewa Beach.

Reviews.Title: “Great Resort!”
Reviews.Author: gmroigmiller
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the JW Ihilani from December 2nd to 5th. We had a mountain view (our room #1601 had a great view of Paradise Cove, Coconut Plantation, Ko Olina Kai & Hillside plus a partial ocean view of the Waianae coast). The staff was great and friendly. The valet guys were eager to help with directions and what to do around the island. The food was great. We enjoyed the lagoons to ourselves everyday. The pool was not huge but a nice size; very private and secluded type of vacation. We will definately come back.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Location Outside of Honolulu”
Reviews.Author: lancelarue
Reviews.Content: We stayed 5 nights at the Ihilani through a marriott rewards special ($748 including tax). The resort itself is very nice - high quality furnishings, big lanais, etc. We had a negative experience on the first night in. we had a nice mountain view room on the 16th floor, room 1601. We returned from dinner and a walk to find a cleaning cart blocking the fire escape right outside of our door, and a work cart with a variety of repair items, including tiles, tile grout, and even a gallon jug of paint thinner! The hallway and our room had a strong odor from the paint thinner. We called and asked to have the items moved, and 15 minutes later found that they had simply moved the items around the corner out of sight. We then asked to be moved. They said they were upgrading us to an oceanview room, but put us in 1219. I recommend against staying in any room ending in 19, as it is in a seem in the building on the ocean side and gives you a 9/10 view of a white wall and a view of the ocean if you lean waaayy over and look out the west end of the lanai - not good. We got moved again to the 6th floor, mountian view and all was well from there on. The service was very good, particularly from the valet folks, who were very prompt, attentive and kind to our 4 year old daughter. The fish feeding at the lagoon at 7:30 a.m. was great. Also, jelly fish come in for 7-10 days after a full moon, but we did not see any, even though we came in on the 8th day following a full moon. The pool was also great-never crowded and great for teaching my daughter to swim. The best thing about the Marriott is that it is away from the crowds of Honolulu, but close enough to be convenient. We drove into Honolulu 3 of the 5 days and went to a nearby exit for supplies and reasonably priced food. You definitely need a car to get everything out of it, unless you are willing to stay in one location. One more point - the 90 minutes to look at the Ko Olina Beach Club down the road is well worth it - we got $150 in credits against our bill, and we also got $30 tickets to the Tuesday night-only luau Fia Fia. This is something you do NOT want to miss. The food was excellent, the setting ideal and the performers top notch. I can't believe they dont have this every night, as it was much better than Germaines down the road and also better than the Hyatt Regency luau on Maui that we attended the year before. All in all, a great place. My only caveat was how they handled having flamable liquids sitting around in the hallway on our first night. We did not let it ruin our trip and we had a great stay.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Hotel - Best Location to get away from it all!”
Reviews.Author: susie6505
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the JW from November 15 to 16, 2005 and loved this hotel. Location is ideal if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of Waikiki and Honolulu. Our room was beautiful! My favorite part was the bathroom. Sunken marble tub with a nice sized shower separate! My husband favorite part of the room was the remote control board by the bed that worked all the lights and TV. I wish we had more time to spend. Loved the Lagoon swim area. Did not see a lot of people at the pool, but looked great! We had only 1 night, but would definitely return. Excellent staff. Did not get a chance to eat at the restaurants, but heard they were all excellent!

Reviews.Title: “First class resort”
Reviews.Author: HighFidelity
Reviews.Content: (I would give 4 1/2 stars if I could). My wife and I spent our 10th anniversary here and absolutely loved this place. It's not cheap, but you definitely get what you pay for. I read some reviews in advance where people complained about the "nickel and diming" you get here, but we did not run into that at all. The staff was very pleasant and helpful and the grounds were beautiful. They have a manmade lagoon (which is 1 of 4 in a row) on the property which offers some pretty decent snorkeling and a nice beach. The pool is a little on the small side but it never seemed to get too crowded. We did not experience the large number kids running around that I read about on this site. They have a couple of fish tanks in the outdoor center of the hotel which are very interesting; one holds 3 stingrays and the other holds baby hammerheads and baby black tip reef sharks. Apparently they catch these and raise them until they get to about 3-4 feet long and then release them into the wild. It's a very surreal thing to watch these predators swim around searching for food in a small tank right in the middle of the resort. We were put in a mountain view room on the top (17th) floor. My only real problem with the whole experience at the Marriott Ihilani was the loud howling sound created by the wind which we experienced in our room. There were very large glass sliding doors leading to the balcony that had a small space at the bottom where air could get underneath. When the wind would blow outside (the tradewinds were just beginning to blow) we would hear a very loud whistling sound. I called down to the lobby to see if we could get a different room, but they could not accommodate. We did notice that as we walked around the hotel we could hear the same sound whenever we got close to any door outside door. I guess it's just a case of bad engineering. Otherwise, the room was spectacular: Huge bathroom with a garden tub, separate shower, separate toilet; a very comfortable bed with many pillows; tons of closet space, and a nice sitting area with a desk and separate sofa. If I had to make one more complaint about an otherwise excellent resort, I would say that it is a bit isolated on the island. It's a trade-off though. If you stay in a convenient area like Honolulu or Waikiki, you have to deal with droves of tourists and over-population. If you stay in Ko Olina at the Marriott, you are a little off the beaten path, but you don't deal with all the crowds. Overall I highly recommend this resort. It's a little bit extra cash, but worth every penny.

Reviews.Title: “sting rays and great view”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We have kids aged 4 and 7 and stayed 2 nights before heading to kauai and we loved it. It was quieter that most hotels, but has great kid stuff to do, especially getting into the water with the affectionate sting rays and feeding baby sharks. The room was large and nice and the lagoon was gentle for young swimmers. staff was great.

Reviews.Title: “Stay Here”
Reviews.Author: avidtraveler10
Reviews.Content: This hotel is excellent except for the food! Great snorkeling, Quiet except at the pool where all the kids are but great beach. The staff is super helpfull and freindly. Great condition quiet area very romantic and peacefull!

Reviews.Title: “Both Romantic and Family Getaway”
Reviews.Author: ladybug01
Reviews.Content: My husband and I were very happy with our stay at the Marriott. When we arrived at the hotel, they upgraded us to an ocean view room for free! After a long 8 hour flight from Houston, that was just what we needed to hear. I don't know if they gave it to us cause he's a Marriott Reward member but we took it with a smile. I think the pool was a perfect size. I didn't have any issues with the children around us. If you want a good view of the ocean, then you should come early to claim your area. The restaurants at the Marriott were expensive so we ended up going to the town closest to the hotel. You can ask the conceirge for directions. Here are some of our favorites: Hana Sushi - they have this cream cheese roll that is baked in the oven that to die for!!!! Kapolei Korean BBQ - it was so yummy that my hubby and I went back twice to eat there. Kularb Thai Restaurant - I thought this place made their food bland but my husband liked it. If you like spicey food make sure you ask them to hook you up. Also, for snorkeling gear and snacks you can check out the Kmart in that same food strip. You can also buy all your chocolate covered Macadamia nuts for our family and friends since it's cheaper than some places. If you are a golfer, you must check out the Koolau Golfcourse! It's close to the mountains and rainforest so expect sprinking once in a while. The views are worth the drive even if your game is not on point.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent resort (and spa!) for a honeymoon”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My husband and I spent 10 days at the Ihilani for our honeymoon. We researched many, many destinations for our honeymoon and narrowed it down to Oahu, since we could fly to Honolulu for free on my frequent flyer miles. Our desire was to do nothing but relax, so the Ihilani was perfect for us. Those who are looking for more active touring, adventure, etc. would be better off at another destination. We didn't rent a car (and didn't care to), but if you want to go off the resort you really need one. Here's our synopsis of the different facilities at the resort: ROOMS: Excellent. Beautiful, spacious bathrooms with a separate soaking tub and shower. Two sink vanities. Very comfortable bed. Furniture is in great condition. Wonderful maid service. Upon arriving, they honored our "special occasion" with a free bottle of champagne in the room. SERVICE: Overall, very nice. The staff was very friendly and accommodating. Restaurant servers were all excellent. RESTAURANTS: We were incredibly surprised by the wonderful food. We set our expectations for mediocre "hotel" food, but actually had excellent meals every night. The variety was wonderful and we ate every meal on the resort and didn't get bored. The Japanese sushi restaurant is not to be missed! Go for the house-smoked salmon sashimi. Breakfast buffet was excellent with a wide variety. The only so-so food was at the pool bar. SPA: If you want to relax, book some spa appointments! It's a splurge (about an average of $150 for an hour of treatment), but well worth it. I had the Lomilomi massage, ginger scrub, rejuvinating wrap, and a manicure (one of the best manicures I've ever had). Everything was wonderful, and you should definitely take advantage of the non-treatment, general services of the spa (steam room, roman pool, needle shower, etc.). It's all incredibly relaxing. GOLF: My husband and I brought our clubs and played 2 rounds of golf. It was incredible. If you don't care about score and are looking to save money, book your tee time for after 2:00 so you can get the twilight rate. It's about $150 for greens fees, $90 for twilight -- we lucked out and got the "aeration" rate of $50. We didn't care about sandy greens, so it was a steal! And there's a Roy's restaurant at the 18th hole so you can have a nice dinner after the round. Wonderful. POOL: I agree with some other reviews that this pool is too small for the resort. But it's a beautiful pool. The music coming from the pool bar is wonderful and the drinks are great! We stuck to pina coladas garnished with fresh pineapple and a beautiful orchid. There were a lot of families with young children around the weekend, so consider this if you're not a huge fan of listening to children play in the pool. (We had fun watching them.) Chairs in the shade were popular -- they were all taken by about 9:30 am, so you had to have a strategy to mark your chairs early. OTHER: We definitely recommend the sunset cruise on the Ko Olina Cat (catamaran). It's about $45 per person which includes 2 drinks per person and light appetizers. It was a blast. There was a good wind that evening, so we were able to go under sail. Incredible, and the crew was very nice. We hope our review helps. We were grateful to have Trip Advisor when planning our honeymoon, so we wanted to return the favor and help others considering their next getaway.

Reviews.Title: “Great palce”
Reviews.Author: dgs146
Reviews.Content: First off, I've read many reviews here and the one thing that I must say is that my wife and I do not usually stay in places this nice and expensive, so as "bang for the buck" goes, I can't compare to other similarly priced hotels elsewhere. We loved this place. I know many people complain about the pool. My wife and I were amazed at how many people stayed around the pool when they had 4 huge and amazing lagoons right after the pool that very few people used. We didn't even use the pool. Why would you want to? As for jelyfish warnings - there weren't any when we were there, not that I'm doubting other reviewers - it just wasn't when we were there. We had an amazing ocean view room, with a comfortable bed, large lanai, huge bathroom, and a perfect view. They pool area had dinner-time entertainment that we heard from our room. It didn't go too late at all and it wasn't too loud, so it provided some nice background noise. We also preferred being so far away from the hustle of Honolulu/Waikiki. It wasn't a long drive and you did need a car, but I never expected to go to Hawaii and not need a car. I've seen many complaints about the food prices. My wife and I had breakfast there both mornings we were there, and it was well worth every penny. They were 2 of the most amazing breakfasts either of us has had in our entire lives! The prices weren't too bad. The buffet is 20+ bucks, bet our meals were around the 15 dollar mark, and well worth every penny. One reviewer wrote they could've gotten dinner at Ruth's Chris. I'm not sure. Our bills for breakfast were about 40-45 after tax/tip and the food was better than Ruth's Chris. Like I said, it was the best breakfast we've ever had. The staff was very helpful and friendly from the moment we checked in until the moment we left. We loved our stay in every aspect and we'd defintely stay there again. Oh, and instead of criticizing the size of the pool and the noise of it, walk the extra distance and go to the 2nd or 3rd lagoon. It's quiet, only a few people, and it'll be like you have part of Hawaii to yourself. Oh, and if you want to avoid the loud kids and families everyone writes about, don't go in the summer. We went in September, and there were a few kids there, but it was not loud at all. We'd stay there again and we wished we stayed longer.

Reviews.Title: “The Best Oahu Has To Offer”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We spent 4 days at the hotel celebrating my husbands retirement. We had 10 rooms and everything went great. No complaints and that is saying something from 20 different people. I would recommend this without any hesitation! A+++ from me!

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely Fabulous!”
Reviews.Author: KaimanaT
Reviews.Content: My family and I just returned from a wonderful 4 night stay at the JW Marriott Ihilani Resort. Of all the times we've stayed at Ko Olina, we've always been treated with the highest customer service. We were so fortunate to not have experience the lack of service other Hawaii residents experienced. When requested, we were allowed to free upgrade to a larger room without any problems. It could be the fact that we don't take advantage of the resident room rate (kamaaina rate) and pay the regular rate as everyone else does. It is possible that you get what you pay for. The restaurants on the property are excellent, however, they are pricey. For example, since we were there to unwind from our business, we don't drive anywhere but just retreat at the hotel, our food bill alone was almost $350 for 2 Adults, 2 kids ages 6 & 4. For this, we would suggest, especially families with kids, to drive off property to the Kapolei shopping center- its about 5 minutes away. There you will find a bunch of eateries and little shops to gather necessities. In regards to recreation, the pool is definately too small for a resort. Sure my kids were one of those who laughed and screamed, as kids often do, however, I made it a point to have them tone it down a bit out of respect for the other guest that were enjoying the area. As far as the pool being too small, my only thought here is maybe it's that way because of the 4 man-made lagoons. Who comes to Hawaii to swim in a pool anyway? Just a thought. But then again, who lives in Hawaii to vacation in Hawaii?- back at me :-) In my opinion, the only thing the lagoons lack is cabanas, at least for lagoon 1 which is situated right in front of the JW. My husband enjoyed running around the resort. I think it may be close to 2 or 3 miles around all 4 lagoon walkways and sidewalk access. Newspapers and daily activity memos are delivered to you room every morning. Even so, the ice bucket was always replenished. Overall, this property has been our favorite weekend getaway on Oahu. Since we live outside of Waikiki, Ko Olina takes us away from all the chaos of city environment. Besides, your vacation will probably take you into Waikiki at least once or twice, therefore, the drive is only 30 minutes away, the only drawback is the morning and afternoon traffic M-F, which could add another hour to that commute.

Reviews.Title: “Read All Reviews”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the JW between Sept. 26 and 30. Unfortunately I did not read any reviews until my return. I read both good and bad reviews and found all of them relevant to my experience. I guess the first impression I had was the location itself. Ko Olina is far from Waikiki and in a very remote location. You MUST have a car if you want to leave the resort grounds, which I strongly advise for ALL meals. The hotel pricing is outrageous for meals. For a standard buffet breakfast, they ask $23.50. At most Marriott's this breakfast is usually $15 at most. It was actually quite amusing to receive a breakfast bill for $60 for two people. Normally I could eat at Ruth's Chris for the same price. I didn't have any negative experiences with staff, but was told that our room was an ocean-view but had two double beds instead of a king size. Everything else was allegedly booked. Those "bookings" must have been relatives of the Invisible Man because the guests sure were not on the property. Being 6'3" and 235 pounds their double bed was only a twin for me. My wife slept in separate "double" beds the whole week. The room and bathroom were unusually large. In fact, I actually measured off the room and made the assessment that you could actually have put (4) of their "double beds" into the room and still have plenty of space. The bathroom was also quite large which my wife appreciated. For me, too many mirrors and seats. I don't want to sit down in the bathroom other than on the toilet. The pool is quite small and shallow. There are many kids present, but that's too be expected. The spa (jacuzzi) was quite dirty with lots of floating debris in it. The lagoons are very appealing to the eye and quite comfortable to swim in. However, as another reviewer pointed out, there were jellyfish warnings posted everywhere. It did not stop me nor many other guests, but I was told that three children had been stung earlier in the day. I didn't do any snorkeling out near the lagoon opening, but was told there were some exotic marine life. One thing that has not been posted much is the very cool shark and sting ray pools on site. They are not interactive, but are very cool to see up close. Overall, it was a pleasant holiday. I don't think I would return to the same location, but cannot really pinpoint why. The whole experience was just "okay". And for the amount of money you're spending for the week, it just isn't worth it. There's something missing there and hopefully I can continue reading reviews to find someone that can articulate what is lacking better than I can describe it myself.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: This is an excellent resort set away from the over crowded Waikiki area. If you want "Spring Break" (think party, party, party) then go to Waikiki. If you want a mature relaxing resort think JW Marriott Iliahani. After a long flight and day of traveling we were welcomed with a quick check in and some refreshing cool towels to wash up. It's the little things here that add up. Like the fresh orchids for the women to put in their hair. Available at the desk for free everyday, or the complimentary Kona coffee available every morning, and the daily newspaper delivery. We found the service to be pleasant and good. Everytime we called downstairs the phone was answered on the first ring with an "Aloha how may we help you?" The rooms are very big and comfortable. The food was great although the resturants are expensive. Try visiting Roy's resturant across the street. You will need a car to get around unless you desire to stay put at the hotel. There is a small town located less than five minutes from the hotel that offers Starbucks and inexpensive dining etc. The lagoons and beaches are quiet and private. I read a previous honeymooner's review about how they complained about almost everything here but we find their review unfounded with the exception that there are a number of familes with children here. If you have children then you will probably like it here but if you want away from the kids be prepared there are a number of children. This did not present a problem though because we often spent the day touring the island anyway, and we found that the familes and children quieted down early in the evening leaving the resort very quiet at night. Furthermore, the comment that no rooms face the ocean is false. Our room faced the ocean and I have an attached photo of the sunset to show. This place is a quality hotel and a peaceful get away....we can't wait to go back.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful and Intimate Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Mr_Skydiver
Reviews.Content: The Ihilani is an exquisite hotel NOT in Waikiki. We wanted a first class and intimate hotel in a more peaceful location since it was our honeymoon. We really loved the Ihilani. We had an oceanfront room in a different wing of the hotel. It's like a 2 or 3 level wing with great sunset views and expansive ocean views. The room was very modern, large, and has a huge marble bathroom. We can say enough about this place. We even did the sting ray tour at the hotel. That was very unique and recommended. We ate at Roy's nearby. That was kind of a dissappointment. I wouldn't really recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Trip of a lifetime!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the JW Marriott Ihilani for a friend's wedding. When we arrived we were so excited by the grand entrance of the hotel. What a beautiful view. After checking in, we were pleasantly surprised by our upgrade to an ocean view room. We overlooked the gardens and the room was spectacular! We spent 3 days relaxing on the beach and 3 days in Honolulu enjoying the night life. The only bad thing about the resort was a lack of food options and how early the bar closed. It was very quiet and not very exciting at night. Even the resort restaurants closed very early or were not open during the week. The wedding was at the hotel and was just breathtaking! It was an incredible event. I would go back to this resort in a second! I hope that I will have a chance to visit again!

Reviews.Title: “Nice, but not worth the $$$”
Reviews.Author: CheesieOne
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Ihilani in May for one night. The isolated location and basically private beach is what captivated us the most about staying here. We paid $450 for one night in a deluxe ocean view room and a contintental breakfast for both of us. Although I thought the room was wonderful and the resort nice, I don't feel that it was worth the $450 that my husband and I paid for it. Prior to Ihilani, we stayed at the Hawaii Prince (in Waikiki) for $150/nite and had better service and rooms that were smaller, but just as nice. Let me tell you a little more about our experience: We checked in and got up to our room only to find that the key didn't work. No big deal except that we had to go back down and get a key that actually worked. The room was very lovely. We had a HUGE closet, separate living area and an amazing bathroom. They even had a fridge except that you can't use it to put your own drinks in because it has a special lock on it with "their" drinks in it. I think it cost something like $3 for a bottled water (which you can expect at a resort). If you want ice, you have to call the maid service to bring it to you (which is done quickly). The great advantage of this resort is that it is basically next door to the Paradise Cove Luau. A shuttle will take you and pick you up from the luau (it's about a 3 minute ride) from Ihilani. The luau is AWESOME and a must see for all vacationers. The view from our balcony was very beautiful (great view of the lagoons and ocean). So beautiful, in fact, that two huge pigeons stole our chaise lounge for the evening to look at the ocean and stars. The only downfall for us was then we couldn't sit in the lounge chair since the birds left little "presents" everywhere! The continental breakfast was good. Made to order omelets, cereal, pastries, etc. The only complaint I have about breakfast is the birds! Birds are everywhere here since the restaurant is open air. My husband caught one of the birds eating my fresh, make-to-order omelet. I guess the birds need to eat too! The lagoon was nice. My husband and I went snorkeling and saw some unique fish by the rocky areas on the edge. After spending the morning at the beach, we ate at the poolside bar and the service was so slow. It took a long time to take our order, get our food, get our check, and even a long time for the waitress to take our money. I think we spent 45 minutes waiting and aobut 5 minutes eating nachos. Normally I would not have cared so much about slower service but we had to clean up and head to the airport to fly home so time was of the essence. Overall impression: Everything at the Ihilani is beautiful except for service. Beautiful rooms, beautiful lagoons, beutiful ocean. Average front desk service, average pool side service, average overall impression. Overall, I am so glad that my husband and I were able to experience the Ihilani, but as I drove away I found myself serioulsly questioning whether it really was worth $450/nite. My final answer is NO...it is not worth the cash for the few extras you get compared to Hawaii Prince (see my review for Hawaii Prince for more info.) in Honolulu.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place, very beautiful, peaceful”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: For our trip to Oahu we spent three nights at the Marriott Ko Olina. It is a beautiful place right on the ocean with great views from about 2/3s of the rooms. We had two rooms on the 9 floor that looked out to the ocean. We were upgraded for free from a garden view. The views were outstanding. I will always be sure to get an ocean view room. It adds a lot to the trip. The rooms were large and beautifully decorated. The grounds of the hotel were nice. There are four lagoons at the hotel property for swimming that are also very beautiful and clean. We also stayed three nights at the Hilton Hawiian Villiage on Waikiki for this trip. My three teenage daughters said "This was how they envisioned hawaii" about the Ko Olina hotel...If you want a nice peaceful, restful, and beautiful resort this is the place. Only negatives I can say is that the hotel is pretty isolated. Your dining choices are very limited unless you want to drive for 20 minutes or so. The hotel is also expensive for dining and the service was good but not excellent. Breakfast for 5 was over $100, and this was eating continental breakfasts..We have been to Hawaii over 7 times and to all the Islands. I would rate this Hotel as one of the top luxury hotels in the islands. It would be a great place to go if you want relaxation, peacefulness, and to get away from the hustle and bustle.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, but not up to the JW Standard”
Reviews.Author: limouser
Reviews.Content: I am a Platinum member with Marriott meaning I stay at Marriott properties at least 75 nites a year. I've stayed at virtually all levels, from Fairfield Inns to JW's to Ritz-Carltons. That said, I have a pretty good idea of level of service to be expected from each type of chain. The JW in Oahu does not provde the level of service that one receives from other JWs. Is it good, but it is not outstanding. Nevertheless, we had a very good time there. We went with another couple (all of us around 40) and had great room overlooking the OPPOSITE side of where the pool is. Very quiet and great sunsets. I highly recommend signing up for going into the pool with the stingray and other creatures.

Reviews.Title: “Retured for the second time”
Reviews.Author: Nyobi
Reviews.Content: We were here on vacation on July 25-27, it was so great we had to come back after staying at the Turtle Bay a few days later. My bf said he had stayed here 5 years ago and he had great memories, so we booked it. The rooms are very spacious and the bathrooms are awsome. Both times we had an awsome views of the ocean, and each time they upgraded our room for free. The Hotel is a very romantic and fun place for the kids(they have a kids club). The live music by the pool was great, they had songs that even small children were singing too, and adults would enjoy. One of the singer there on one night was a former Miss Hawaii. The lagoons were great, altho the sand was not as nice as Maui, but the best we saw on the island. The pool was somewhat lacking in design, as it was a shallow circle, although it looked awsome when it was lit up at nite from one of the top lanai's. The gift shop there is outrageously prices, as with any resort, another neat this is that they have a CD player in the room and u can borrow CDs for free from the Concierge's desk. If you're debating on where to stay, stop debating and choose this place. It's great because you're out of the dirty bustle of Waikkiki, and you're not way out as the North Shore, this place is perfect for you. Also there is great places to eat such as Jack in the Box and other tasy food you can't live without, just 3 miles away.

Reviews.Title: “Jammed with Noisy Kids ...”
Reviews.Author: Choulli
Reviews.Content: Jammed with Noisy Kids ... which is fine, if that's what you want (or if that's who you are). BUT, if you're a couple on your honeymoon, looking for a relaxing atmosphere with beautiful scenery (as we were) then this is not for you. It certainly wasn't for US & I really wish that I had known about the atmosphere here, BEFORE we booked our honeymoon stay at the Ihilani. I must add that we are both mature adults in our late thirties & seasoned travelers who have stayed in hotels all over the world. The staff here can be pleasant enough (try to make a friend or 2 so that you can get some inside advice), but they never go the extra mile it would take to make them memorable. And sadly, they lie. Blatantly. Upon booking our room, I was told that our Deluxe Ocean View room would have a FULL PANORAMIC VIEW OF THE OCEAN & instead, our balcony view was of the ugly industrial park at Barber's Point & of the Ko'Olina under construction, complete with industrial cranes (see my pics). When I asked the desk clerk what happened to our 'full panoramic ocean view', she sheepishly admitted that NONE of the rooms actually face the ocean. Not actually??? After flying 10 1/2 hours, we didn't appreciate this technicality. The hotel pool & hot tub were jammed w screaming kids, morning, noon & night. No exaggeration. We don't dislike children, but we don't want them invading our expensive, $400.00 a-night-room-vacation either. This factor really diminished the quality of the hotel & the enjoyment of our stay. And, there were constantly big, noisy weddings (almost every day), on every inch of the property. This is the poorer, drier side of the island. Outside of the hotel grounds, there is very little to see or do. Rent a car so that you may explore the lovely northshore & east side of Oahu & by all means, go to the Kapolei Shopping Center for a few of your meals (try Julie Z & En Fuego for some great, local food & at decent price) or drive north to Hale'wa town, which has some terrific restaurants (pronounced ha-LEE-va) or you'll go broke eating at the Ihilani. Lastly, we reserved a table for our wedding night dinner, thinking it would be a wonderful & romantic experience. Our meal at Azul was probably the worst that we had on Oahu & the service was far below par, for what the Ihilani bills as 'An Award Winning Restaurant'. I'd be curious to know what awards it has won exactly - perhaps it was the Below Average, Ho Hum Dining & Average Service award? As a newly-married couple (less than an hour to be exact - we were married on the beach, behind the hotel) we should have been given a bottle of champagne, SOMETHING to acknowledge the obvious (I was in my gown & the staff was told WELL in advance, MANY times, that this was our wedding dinner for 2) ... yet nothing special materialized, even though we were guests at the hotel for 11 nights. The bottom line for us is that the Ihilani isn't special, nor is it unique or worthwhile. We would have gotten far more enjoyment had we rented a shack on the beach of the scenic north shore & watched the sun set each evening. In peace & quiet!

Reviews.Title: “Great place”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My wife and 4 year old twins stayed here in late June/early July and had a great time. Rooms are outstanding...very large even for not the top view. Pool is average but beach is outstanding and service terrific. The 5 hotel restaurants are good but expensive and you need a car if you want to get out. 2 cities 5 and 10 minutes from the hotel offer plenty of other dining options, especially for kids. If you want another gourmet meal, however, you need to head downtown or to Waikiki. Marriott is building a Beach Club (timeshare) there as well and those rooms are great and about a 10 minute walk from the Ihilani. We would definitely go back.

Reviews.Title: “THE Definitive Report!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: My fiance' and I just returned home to Los Angeles on July 26th after 5 great nights at the Ihilani. We had intended to stay at the 5 star, adults only resort Secrets Excellence in Riviera Maya (Cancun) but, a grumpy lady named Emily changed that at the last minute! We had to make some very quick decisions and went with trading in our margaritas for mai tai's. Of course I checked trip advisor to do my last minute research and saw a wide range of reviews. I determined to write a "definitive" report to help sort out the current state of the resort and deny or corroborate others postings. Of course vacations are always subjective but I've done a fair amount of traveling to various areas at various pricing tiers and I feel somewhat qualified. I always wonder about the background of posters so I will let you know that I am a 28 year old male who works for an International Wine Brand in sales. I'm accustomed to fine dining and am by no means a snob who can't be pleased but I'm not a "pushover" either. If there is no traffic you can get to the resort from the airport in 20-25 minutes. Rush hour (3-6pm) will make that trip 1 hour plus. The resort is located on the "Leeward" side of the island; SW. All of the hawaiian islands have a leeward side and a windward side that are very similar. The leeward side is drier and sunnier and the windward side is more lush and rainy. The hotel is located within the Ko Olina resort area which is guarded with cameras and friendly staff who welcome you back from your excursions. It is a very beautiful entrance with ponds and waterfalls situated right next to the golf course. The general feel of the hotel itself is Understated Elegance, NOT Oppulence. The lobby is very clean but lacks a dramatic centerpiece which would be nice as it makes the first impression besides the drive up. You do not want a Mountain View room here, the ocean views are not to be missed. We stayed in room 620 which had incredible Sunset ocean views! Request a "sunset" view room as the other ocean views are located above the noisy pool area. From our lanai you could only see other lanai's, the sting ray and fish pond, the mountains in the distance and swaying palm trees just before the ocean which I could have hit with a stone. There are only 2 "jaw-dropping" things about this resort; the sunset views and the final bill! It is expensive but the serene beauty of the resort area is enough to subdue your left brain temporarily. We went on an exploratory walk upon arrival which I highly recommend. The layout of the resort is very user friendly, no issues here. The 4 natural/man-made lagoons are simply awesome! I wish we would have utilized them more; we took a dip in the bath water temperature lagoon only once. The water is pretty but the sun would have to be shining very brightly for the snorkeling to be worthwhile. If the first lagoon is too crowded for your liking, just walk a few hundred yards to the next one and it is far quieter. By the time you get to the last lagoon you may be the only one there! By the way, there are two very nice timeshare properties right by the third lagoon, they are Marriott Vacation Clubs and they are spectacular! If you are thinking of owning a timeshare--this would be the place to buy. The 90 minute presentation is offered to all Ihilani guests and they give you ONE of 3 different prizes for your time: 15,000 rewards points, $100 dollars of resort money, or two tickets for the catamaran sailing/snorkel/dolphin watching excursion that leaves from the adjacent marina. Each of these tickets costs $100.00 each so, duh, the best bet is to take the tickets. The 3 hour trip was a lot of fun and you never even lose sight of the Ihilani. We snorkeled on a small but nice reef that had water visibility of about thirty feet--a good beginner snorkeler tour. We saw a pod of about 30 Spinner dolphins that did a few nice aeriel acrobatics for us. Snacks and unlimited cocktails are included. Heads up on the timeshare, 1 week of ocean views per year will cost you $41,000.00 at present and these prices are sure to go up, up, up. Financing is for 10 years with 10% down and an initial APR of 14%. A great investment though--these things are not just yours for life, they get willed to your children and grandchildren. We would have done it, but just bought two weeks at the Marriott Shadow Ridge in Palm Desert, California. The Ko Olina property is the #1 most requested area to trade to, so basically you need to own there to be guaranteed a vacation there. Just an FYI. Back to the Ihilani... This resort is billed as having the best kid's club in all of Hawaii, so be prepared--there are perhaps more children under the age of 12 at this resort than there are adults. If you are taking a "family" vacation, your kids will think they have died and gone to heaven! The place where they tend to congragate and make the most noise is also the largest snafu of the resort--the pool! What were the resort makers thinking with this pool? It is absolutely tiny for a resort of this size! At 4ft max depth it is just a plain old circle pool that is no larger than 40ft wide! Kids will be kids, it is not their fault. However the splashing and occasional shrieking of kids in utter jubilation may be too much for the adults to endure. I love kids, and I must say that I do envy their utter disregard for high society and ettiquette but it's going to --- some people off. Just keep this in mind as you are turning red and about to towel smack some annoying kid who just soaked you, your cigar and added the wonderful taste of chlorine to your mai tai: At one time you also knew how to let loose and have fun regardless of what others thought about it--in fact, you didn't even need "helpers" such as alcohol to get the party started! Let them have their fun--sooner or later the world and our "adult" ideas takes it out of them; or, atleast, most of them. In fact, the concept of vacation is foreign to them--from what does a child need a vacation from? We should learn from those little whipper snappers! That said, I hope someone who makes decisions at the resort sees this and builds an adults only pool pronto!! There are only two bars in the resort and the one that serves quick lunch fare is right next to the tiny revelers. If you must have a pool and peace and quiet; there is a small lap pool over on top of the spa by the gym which has no kids but only about a dozen lounge chairs--if you get there early enough, say by 11am you could have your own little quiet adults only spot. In the same location is also a very small jacuzzi that seats perhaps 4 replicas of Mary Kate and Ashley Olson. The only other jacuzzi is full of the revelers :). The only other significant dissapointment of the resort was the Spa. We had a couples massage and the massage itself was very good, (pricey though, at $125 per person for 50min.) probably my second favorite of all time. The dissapointment was in the facility itself which is sorely lacking in amenities and general areas. Men and women are separate sides, no problem here. But my fiance' said the same as me, there was nothing to do besides wait for our appointment in our robes. The mens side had 1 small cold plunge pool, 1 high pressure shower, 1 small sauna and 1 small steam room and that is it besides the waiting room. Same on the ladies side except they don't get the cold plunge pool. The ambiance just wasn't there; no incense burning, no essential oil smells in the common areas, no lush tropical plants decorating the place, no soothing music playing. I honestly do not see what this spa had won awards for. Many spas you could go to at a resort and spend half a day or even a full day enjoying its ammenities and free common areas. With the Ihilani spa you will perhaps get thirty minutes max besides your treatment before total boredom sets in. By the way, do not wait in the outdoor waiting area unless you feel like donating some of your blood to the local mosquito community. The only location I had any trouble with these pests was at the Spa! Also, they automatically bill you for a 17% gratuity! Pardon me, but if you are charging it automatically--IT'S NOT A GRATUITY!! Suppose I hated my massage, what then? It should just be advertised as an all inclusive price at $146.25 rather than the advertised $125.00. It was kind of insulting. Two years ago we stayed at the Aventura Spa Palace in Riviera Maya and that spa put the Ihilani to total shame, period. The Ihilani really needs to spend some money to beautify and add to their spa or significantly reduce their fees. It was the one thing that really made us see that Mexico has caught up to and in many cases surpassed Hawaii as the best vacation spot for Americans. Many hotels in Riviera Maya are oppulent with decadent spas at more reasonable prices. If you are a spa afficionado and are going to this resort, you will be dissapointed. Don't get too down though, here's some good stuff. The cocktails at this resort were very reasonable, I expected them to stick it to us in this area. A delicious Mai Tai will set you back only $8 bucks and they make other great concoctions at $8 or less. Martini drinkers listen up, every night from 9-11pm the Hokule'a bar has martini happy hour and all selections are only $5 bucks. For the beer drinkers they have some good selections for only $3 bucks as well as selected wines at the same price. The pool bar has on tap: Fosters, Heineken, Sam Adams and the other escapes my mind. The food is very pricey and only average at the Naupaka restaurant (Usually a buffet that depending upon what the theme night is will be from $36 per person up to $45.00) Only ate there once. We did not try their flagship restaurant Azul because many of the entrees were in the FORTY dollar range. Excuse me, but who besides a millionaire is not going to strongly wince at those prices! Lunch at the pool grill was Ok and not too expensive. Our favorite meal was at the Japanese place called Usheio Tei. The sushi was good and my fiance' got the grilled lobster which was yummy. We split a large Asahi and after tip still spent $120.00. Yikes! If you want to be able to pay your mortgage when you get home, eat some meals in the nearest town, Kapolei, which is 6 minutes by car. There is a totally inexpensive Thai place called Ku Larb Thai that had some of the best thai cuisine I've ever had. The place itself is not aesthetically pleasing at all and the service is lax but the food--MMMMMMM!! $30-40 bucks for two including tip and you leave stuffed to the gills. Also, if you like Sushi, in the same lot as the thai place is Hana Sushi. I live in the sushi mecca of Los Angeles and this place was way cheaper than LA sushi and it was also way better; I can't think of better sushi anywhere--absolutely fresh with great service and casual ambience. Dinner for two without drinks was $40-50 bucks and we ate there twice. I forgot to mention the gym; it was very good, really impressed with the new equipment and selection. Plenty of treadmills, one stair stepper, a few ellipticals, plenty of free weights, and machines for chest, stomach and back. Props to the Ihilani for getting the gym very much right. The rooms at the resort are first rate. The bathroom is nice with two marble sinks, a seperate large shower with ledge, private enclosed toilet and soaking tub. A previous poster said they were two person tubs--only if again, you are the Olsen twins! Mini bar is well stocked and the safe is idiot proof. The bed was "other worldly" comfortable and induced sleep rapidly--which could be a bad thing. ;) There was a seating area with couch and two chairs, desk and coffee table. The lanai was great with one reclining lounge (padded) and two padded chairs and a table sufficient to hold a good amount of room service (though we never ordered any.) Plenty of closet space and hangers. Good selection of channels on TV. (we did have the misfortune of it being "Shark Week" on the discovery channel which is quite addicting but made it very difficult not to be spooked while snorkeling or swimming in the ocean.) Housekeeping was great and usually within a few hours of us leaving the room, only once did we get back and found her still cleaning. We tipped her $4.00 a day and got some delicious chocolate covered strawberries for our generosity. Wow, this is a long review! Overall, I was very impressed with the Island of Oahu--I had visited Kauai 6 years previous and loved it too. I think I prefer Oahu though. We did the North Shore which is beautiful and nice to see how the country folk/natives live. We didn't encounter any hostile or angry locals--just saw a few roadside signs that protested "American occupation of the islands". I highly recommend the Diamond Head hike. The views of Waikiki and Honolulu from up there are breathtakingly gorgeous. If you build up an appetite on the short hike and feel like a gooey cheeseburger you can go to Cheeseburger Waikiki or Cheeseburger in Paradise. Order the "it's all good" and soon your body will be in a cholesterol coma! Haunama bay has the best snorkeling on the island, (along with Lanikai beach which you can only reach by kayak unless you go through someones yard.) I highly recommend both! Lanikai is the most gorgeous beach and ocean I have ever seen but I've never been to Tahiti. It blows Poipu beach in Kauai out of the water and that beach won Travel Channels best beach in the world for like 3 straight years--I can't believe you don't hear more about Lanikai beach. Frommer's guide said that the Waikiki Aquarium is a "do not miss." You must be joking! Skip this at all costs! The resort lagoons with rays and little reef sharks and hammerheads is 10X more exciting. We were done with the whole tour in less than 10 minutes, no joke. The sharks are what everyone goes to the aquarium to see and they have a total of 3 (no joke). If you added up their cumulative lengths they would be about as long as Jaws dorsal fin! Stop by and see Fannie, one of the resorts concierges' and she will help you with excursions. Everything she recommend we did and she was spot on. We really enjoyed ourselves on this much needed vacation and you will find the setting of this resort both romantic and visually beautiful--but not oppulent. We expected more when room rates are $400-500plus per night. We would return for a family vacation but not for just the two of us--there are too many super adults only spots in Mexico and the Carribean to do it again. Feel free to email me with any questions and I promise to reply: jryanomalley@earthlink.net. Enjoy yourself--It is a vacation, time to splurge on food, drink and not worry about the money. :)

Reviews.Title: “Last minute trip to detour from Dennis”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this resort July 12 thru 17th. It was a last minute planned vacation. We were originially going to Destin, Flordia. So glad our plans changed thanks to Dennis, the hurricane. We loved this resort. The staff was amazing. They were quick to accommodate any request. Our room was the biggest We had ever stayed in. The view of the mountains, ocean and the lagoon were breathtaking. We were in room #520, which had two double beds, a sitting area and a very large bathroom with double sinks, shower stall and a separate tub. Do rent a car and tour the rest of the island. The hotel will give you printed directions and make suggestions as to where to go and what to see. Honolulu is about 25 minutes away. If you like to shop go the the Aloha tower Marketplace on Honolulu Harbor. Also go to the Ala Moana shopping mall. Go to the Paradise Cove Luau. It was a lot of fun. If you have kids go to the Hawaiian Waters Adventure Park. We took our two teenagers. It was a great day of fun. They loved the Flow Rider. My husband and I went to the Bahamas in February and were surprised at how unfriendly the people were. This was not the case here. Everyone from the staff at the Resort to to the locals we incountered where exceptional friendly. Can't wait to go back the the J.W. Marriott Ihilani Resort.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful rooms, but by no means perfect”
Reviews.Author: NickyAlameda_CA
Reviews.Content: We stayed at this hotel in June. We were initially put in a room with a big wall to look out at. The staff changed our room and we were put into a very nice ocean view room (as requested) on the north part of the triangle. Bottom line: the rooms are beautiful (one of the best I've stayed in), the pool is too small and as another reviewer wrote, it was overun with children playing football in it. Chairs are packed around the very small pool. The beach is where we wanted to be, but there is limited shade to be had and the lagoons are a bit fake looking. I saw two fish when I went snorkling. Food was marginal at best. In fact the Azul restaurant refunded our money because our shrimp and scallops were charred. I'm generally pretty easy to please, but this hotel was lacking in some very important areas: food and the beach. But you can't complain about the rooms! Slept very well~

Reviews.Title: “What a beautiful place!”
Reviews.Author: LisaandAdam
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at the JW for our honeymoon, checking in on May 29th and leaving on June 7th. I had read every single review on this web site and others on multiple hotels before deciding on the Ihilani. What a great descision! I reserved directly through the hotel and purchased the honeymoon package for two nights and got a Marriott Rewards discount for the remaining five nights (even though the discounted room nights were suppose to be in Standard Mountain View they left us in the Deluxe Ocean View). We arrived at 7:00p and there was no wait to check in. Our bags made it to our room just minutes after we did, and a few minutes after that champagne and strawberries showed up (yummy)! We ordered room service (after we learned how to use the phone) for dinner and called it a night. Day one was spent at the spa. The layout is a little rough with the guys being on the first floor, check in on the third floor with the ladies area and treatment rooms, the lap pool on the fifth floor, and finally tennis courts on top of the roof. Still a very nice spa with reasonable prices. Make sure you have lunch delivered to the lap pool. No kids (usually nobody at all) to bother you, which is nice. Days two through four were spent at the resort. We ate at every food outlet* they have and got to know one of the pool bartenders quite well (make sure you tell Allen that the newlyweds from Orlando said hello and that we hope him and his wife can make it out here). I'll list the restaurants and our ratings of them. Room Service/Spa - fast efficient and they bring everything you need Pool Bar - pretty much the same as room service Naupaka Terrace - above average resort food Ushio Tei - above average Japanese restaurant, excellent sushi Azul - incredible pacific rim/fusion cuisine, don't miss this *We didn't eat at Roy's across the street at the golf course mainly because we have one right by our house. Day five and six we rented a car at the Hertz at the hotel. Very convenient, we booked ahead of time, picked up the keys and drove off. The hotel concierge was very helpful in setting everything up for us, including billing most of the tours directly to our room. TOO convenient! They were very knowledgable and were able to help us sift through a multitude of options and make the best of our two days away from the resort. Day seven was our last full day at the resort and we decided to do the Time Share thing. They are serious when they say no pressure and it wasn't a complete waste of time. We didn't buy, but they at least piqued our curiosity and added 15,000 Marriott Rewards points to our account.
